title: Salmonella case in Adelaide: Man sick after eating CORE Powerfoods meal
text:
An Adelaide man remains in hospital after being struck down from eating a CORE Powerfoods frozen meal, which was urgently recalled on Monday.

Corey Monaghan, 23, was one of three people in South Australia sick from salmonella after consuming the affected frozen meals. Nationally 15 cases have been reported.

His partner of five years Brooklyn Kuhl said her boyfriend ate the frozen meals on Thursday and Friday night before waking up on Saturday 2.30am feeling horribly sick.

The couple initially thought Mr Monaghan had a gastro bug but he made frequent trips to the toilet.

media_camera Salmonella victim Corey Monaghan and partner Brooklyn Kuhl. He was sick from eating CORE Powerfoods frozen meals. Picture: Brooklyn Kuhl

About 10 hours later, they called an ambulance and the apprentice tiler was taken to Flinders Medical Centre.

“The worst of it was on Sunday night, he was in a lot of pain and had stomach cramps,” Ms Kuhl, 22, said.

“He’s a lot better now … he doesn’t have a lot of energy and feels very tired.”

Ms Kuhl said her partner has eaten CORE Powerfoods frozen meals before but this was the first time he was sick.

He is expected to be discharged from hospital on Saturday.

She said they would be “chucking them all in the bin”.

In a separate case, Angel Knoblauch, 21, of Panorama, said she suffered stomach cramps and threw up on Monday morning after eating the frozen meal on Saturday night.

“I went to Flinders (hospital) that same morning and I didn’t know about the recall then because it wasn’t happening at that time,” she said.

She was released from hospital late Monday morning.

media_camera CORE Powerfoods have recalled some of their frozen meals due to salmonella risk. Picture: CORE Powerfoods / Facebook

SA Health urges people with CORE Powerfoods in their freezer with a best before date from 26/08/2020 — 4/10/2020 inclusive to throw them away or return to the place of purchase for a refund.

“While this particular type of Salmonella is unusual, any kind of Salmonella poses serious health risks and symptoms of infection can begin anywhere between six and 72 hours after exposure and last for three to seven days,” Fay Jenkins, SA Health director for food and controlled drugs, said.

“These symptoms include fever, diarrhoea, vomiting, headaches, stomach cramps and loss of appetite.”
description: An Adelaide man is in hospital after contracting salmonella from a CORE Powerfoods frozen meal, which were urgently recalled on Monday.
